how is a node assigned to a shard?   based on its account address?    is it dynamic or static?   can i find and reference?

author: djrtwo
content:
Nodes can choose to run whatever shards they want to.

Validators (which run nodes) are randomly assigned to build/validate a subset of shards at any given time

author: arnetheduck
content: in early discussions, loosely, we've been aiming for running perhaps 10 validators per beacon node as a way to amortize networking costs - that however assumes that 10 validators meaningfully cuts down the load on a shard - how is this affected when moving to 64 shards? we've already identified the increased "traffic" between shard and beacon (because each shard is voted on every slot) - but  what is the effect on number of validators that a single beacon node can support (network, processing wise)?

author: djrtwo
content:
- The load on the beacon chain is roughly the same (within ~2x from previous proposal)
- There is now no shard attestations -- so slight reduction in network load on shard subnets from that
- Each shard chain will have approximately the same computational gas limit as expected in the past (think ~1 eth1 chain)
- Shardblock size target is 8x (projected). This is based on some research on eth1 block propagation that showed that it is safe  (wrt propagation times and uncle rates) to have much larger blocks. This is the main thing that would change your resource per validator estimates in the new proposal as the bandwidth from shard blocks is higher

author: djrtwo
content:
--------
There are some nuances here that need to be considered. For example, assume you participate in the shard attestation subnet for the entire epoch length. There are attestations sent on that subnet _every_ slot now rather than just one slot for the entire epoch. So if you naively stay listening to that net for the entire epoch, you get 32x (epoch_length) bandwidth on your node from beacon attestations.

author: djrtwo
content:
> is there any  refence on   "nodes choose their shard"?

So you run any amount of shards that you need for your node. If you have an application that lives on shard 1, yuo might fully sync shard1, and then lightly (via light client protocol) sync other shards you are interacting with. A lot of this is highly dependent on your use case.

Generally, you sync the beacon chain and then sync whatever shard chains you want, or request data about specific portions of shards via the latest crosslinks in the beacon chain
